articles.headline: As ISIS Is Driven From Iraq, Sunnis Remain Alienated
articles.snippet: The grievances of Iraq’s Sunni Arab minority allowed the Islamic State to flourish. How the government deals with Sunnis now could have long-term consequences.
articles.abstract: The grievances of Iraq’s Sunni Arab minority allowed the Islamic State to flourish. How the government deals with Sunnis now could have long-term consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARMAH, Iraq — After the Islamic State was finally driven from the central Iraqi city of Karmah last year, Sirhan Sallom returned to his home to find it demolished.

articles.headline: Russia Fanned Flames With Twitter, Which Faces a Blowback
articles.snippet: A troll account linked to Moscow shows how easily social media fanned the flames of outrage. Unlike other tech giants, Twitter could have a harder time dealing with the fallout.
articles.abstract: A troll account linked to Moscow shows how easily social media fanned the flames of outrage. Unlike other tech giants, Twitter could have a harder time dealing with the fallout.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Fires need fuel. In this era of political rage, a Twitter account that called itself the unofficial voice of Tennessee Republicans provided buckets of gasoline.

articles.headline: Following the (Bike) Trail to Amazon’s Second Headquarters
articles.snippet: Among the factors that will affect where the company chooses to put its new headquarters: cost, diversity, universities — and coffee roasters.
articles.abstract: Among the factors that will affect where the company chooses to put its new headquarters: cost, diversity, universities — and coffee roasters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon said this week it had received proposals from 238 cities and regions across North America that are vying for its new, second headquarters, called HQ2. No wonder: With a prize of 50,000 high-paying jobs, a promised $5 billion in construction spending and the prestige of having a headquarters for one of the world’s fastest-growing, best-known tech companies, the contest is vastly more important than a World Series or Super Bowl.

articles.headline: J.F.K. Files, Though Incomplete, Are a Treasure Trove for Answer Seekers
articles.snippet: President Trump ordered the long-awaited release of more than 2,800 documents that investigators, historians and conspiracy theorists hope hold more clues to what happened on Nov. 22, 1963.
articles.abstract: President Trump ordered the long-awaited release of more than 2,800 documents that investigators, historians and conspiracy theorists hope hold more clues to what happened on Nov. 22, 1963.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ordered the long-awaited release on Thursday of more than 2,800 documents related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, but bowed to pressure from the C.I.A. and F.B.I. by withholding thousands of additional papers pending six more months of review.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Scott Shane

articles.headline: What Worries? Big Tech Companies Post Glowing Quarterly Profits
articles.snippet: Some are heading to Washington to explain their role in the 2016 election. Others are facing regulatory scrutiny. Consumers don’t seem to care.
articles.abstract: Some are heading to Washington to explain their role in the 2016 election. Others are facing regulatory scrutiny. Consumers don’t seem to care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big technology companies are being dragged in front of Congress to answer tough questions about their impact on the 2016 presidential election, and their market power is under increasing scrutiny.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: U.S. Soldiers Were Separated From Unit in Niger Ambush, Officials Say
articles.snippet: New details have changed the timeline to the attack as Pentagon officials investigate the ambush that left four Americans and five Nigeriens dead.
articles.abstract: New details have changed the timeline to the attack as Pentagon officials investigate the ambush that left four Americans and five Nigeriens dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the chaotic moments after an Army Special Forces team and 30 Nigerien troops were ambushed by militants in a remote corner of West Africa three weeks ago, four of the Americans were separated from the larger group.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: CVS Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Aetna in Landmark Acquisition
articles.snippet: The proposed deal, which could be worth more than $60 billion, would accelerate the health care industry’s transformation.
articles.abstract: The proposed deal, which could be worth more than $60 billion, would accelerate the health care industry’s transformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CVS Health, the giant drugstore chain that also runs walk-in clinics and a pharmacy benefit business, is in talks to buy Aetna, one of the nation’s largest health insurance companies, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Michael J. de la Merced and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Nordic-Style Designs Sit at Heart of French Labor Plan
articles.snippet: In selling economic changes to a dubious public, President Emmanuel Macron is promising expanded unemployment benefits and revamped training programs.
articles.abstract: In selling economic changes to a dubious public, President Emmanuel Macron is promising expanded unemployment benefits and revamped training programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The people running France would like to clear up what they contend is an unfortunate misunderstanding: They are not ditching the egalitarian ideals of French society for the ravages of global capitalism.

articles.headline: How to Be a C.E.O., From a Decade’s Worth of Them
articles.snippet: Adam Bryant has interviewed 525 chief executives through his years writing the Corner Office column. Here’s what he has learned.
articles.abstract: Adam Bryant has interviewed 525 chief executives through his years writing the Corner Office column. Here’s what he has learned.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started with a simple idea: What if I sat down with chief executives, and never asked them about their companies?

articles.headline: Spain Dismisses Catalonia Government After Region Declares Independence
articles.snippet: Spain’s prime minister said the central government would take control of Catalonia, and he dissolved the regional parliament and ordered new elections.
articles.abstract: Spain’s prime minister said the central government would take control of Catalonia, and he dissolved the regional parliament and ordered new elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Spain’s leader fired the government of the rebellious Catalonia region Friday, dissolved the regional parliament and ordered new elections after Catalan lawmakers illegally declared an independent nation.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: U.S. Economy’s 3% Spurt Emboldens Tax Cut Supporters (and Critics)
articles.snippet: Republicans said the new G.D.P. report signaled increased business spending in anticipation of a corporate tax cut, though many economists are skeptical.
articles.abstract: Republicans said the new G.D.P. report signaled increased business spending in anticipation of a corporate tax cut, though many economists are skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy is showing increased signs of resilience.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: A Student Loan Nightmare: The Teacher in the Wrong Payment Plan
articles.snippet: After $70,000 in payments, one teacher found that he wasn’t in the public service loan forgiveness program after all. Now, he has to start over.
articles.abstract: After $70,000 in payments, one teacher found that he wasn’t in the public service loan forgiveness program after all. Now, he has to start over.
articles.lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — On the first floor of a government building at Olive Street and West 10th Avenue here, Jed Shafer spends his days helping adolescents get their high school equivalency diplomas.

articles.headline: How Floyd Mayweather Helped Two Young Guys From Miami Get Rich
articles.snippet: Celebrity endorsements are helping start-ups raise big money in so-called initial coin offerings. But it is not always clear what they are selling.
articles.abstract: Celebrity endorsements are helping start-ups raise big money in so-called initial coin offerings. But it is not always clear what they are selling.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Floyd Mayweather, perhaps the greatest boxer of his generation, is not shy about using social media to display the wealth that his years of prize fighting have won him. On Facebook, you can find videos of Mr. Mayweather draped in diamond chains. Want to see him with blocks of $100 bills taped to his torso? There’s that, too.

articles.headline: In a Mortgage-Crisis Settlement, Did a Bank Get Off Easy?
articles.snippet: An accord with the Justice Department requires Credit Suisse to pay $2.8 billion in consumer relief, but others are providing much of it.
articles.abstract: An accord with the Justice Department requires Credit Suisse to pay $2.8 billion in consumer relief, but others are providing much of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, prosecutors concluded one of the last multibillion-dollar settlements related to the 2008 mortgage collapse. The deal, with Credit Suisse, required the bank to pay $2.48 billion to settle allegations that its securities unit had misled buyers of home-loan bundles it had sold between 2005 and 2007.
